body: I'd prefer there be another filename that is used rather than using the same one in different locations to be the trigger. One of the benefits of XDG paths is the decluttering of `$HOME`.

One more advantage of merging config files is the easier management of config as alacritty evolves. This would allow having only the custom settings in a config file, and all of the default ones would be merged in from the default config.

Reducing the filesize of `.config/alacritty/alacritty.yml` is a nice win indeed.

Sidenote: it drives me crazy that it's named `alacritty.yml` and not `config` or `config.yml`, even though it hardly matters.

Alternatively, a directory could be read instead of specific paths. For example, anything matching `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/alacritty/conf.d/*.yml` is read in ASCII-betical order and later files override previous files.

I thought about merging multiple yml files as well, but then there would still be no way to override mouse and keyboard bindings without modifying the original configuration file. Here is an example mouse binding:
```yml
mouse_bindings:
  - { mouse: Middle, action: PasteSelection }
```
and keyboard
```yml
key_bindings:
  - { key: V,        mods: Control|Shift,    action: Paste               }
  - { key: C,        mods: Control|Shift,    action: Copy                }
```
We would either need to write special bindings merging logic that merges entries in the array by `mouse` and `key` + `mods` attributes, or refactor the config files and have these attributes as keys in the yml.

Why would it need to be special logic? Or do you mean "more complicated than `HashMap::extend`" when loading configuration files? The keybindings is a list. I'd just have it append all of those entries together and then `.collect()` them into the final keybinding table. There may need to be a special way to say "bind this key to no action" to "delete" a prior binding.

> "more complicated than HashMap::extend"

Yea. But not much. When collecting the entries, it would have to apply the last entry wins strategy indexed by `key` and `mods` for keyboard bindings. So it is possible to override the default bindings.
I wonder if we can merge the default YAML files a little bit more? What happens if we have both Super and Command keybindings for a given OS?
I'd expect that you'd have multiple keybinds which do the same action. This would be useful for Apple hardware with non-Apple keyboards, but I guess macOS does its own translations internally?

For this to work, every piece of software that is cross-platform, but with different settings per platform, would have to implement their own logic for merging and overwriting configs. I would much rather have this logic exist in whatever syncing/dotfile management tool is being used, than have more complicated inheritance in multiple apps.

I also sync my dotfiles across platforms using plain old git ( http://github.com/jedahan/dotfiles ), and just have two branches, on for macOS and one for linux. I could imagine some sort of cat + diff + cut + paste magic, or something more robust as post receive hooks to merge files automatically.

If you had alacritty.local, and that was synced, then you have the same issue of per-platform config right? Now you have to choose between syncing or manual per-platform management, and if you are already managing synced files per-platform, then the logic wouldn't need to be in alacritty, right?

TLDR: Keep configs DRY, allow people to use one config for macOS and Linux.

I'm not sure we *need* to allow multiple config files and a inheritance (with some precedence rules). What I *do* think we should do is give each config option a default (hardcoded) so that a config file is optional, and then make the config file simply overrule the defaults. This will make a user's config file only related to things he/she cares about, which in turn solves, at least my own cross platform issue, since the main settings I care about are colors and fonts. Users should only need to configure that which they want to change.

I do however think a more general approach would be cool since it doesn't make life harder for the user, but simply allows for more kinds of configurations without external tools.

An alternative to hardcoded defaults for some configurations, which in some cases would need to be specific to some platforms (i.e. keybindings), would be to break the configurations into separate files. For example:

```
.config/alacritty/
    config.yml
    keybindings.yml
```

Here the `config.yml` contains only the few settings the user actually cared about setting (defaulting the rest) and `keybindings.yml` would contain all of the user's keybindings (presumably copied from a standard file we provide like today).
So what's the solution right now?  I have different fonts I like to look at on mac and ubuntu/linux enviornments.  what can be done?

How would you disable built in keybindings in the case where we merge the config file with the default settings?

It would also be cool if you could override any config from the command line.

@chrisduerr I agree with you in general that we shouln't be overly concerned with solving all the problems of user configuration environments. There are other better tools... That said, I'm strongly in favor of something that would allow us to unify the macOS/Linux/Window configs, and only provide the differing subsets as OS specific files. I think that a sane solution for this could help with some peoples issues as well.

@nixpulvis Oh yeah, my comments were just about merging multiple different configuration files together. I'm 100% in favor of merging the macos/linux/windows configuration files together, that will actually save us a lot of work in the long run.

I don't think it's necessary to provide different files for that though, things like default fonts could be handled by making the value optional for example and then substituting it in the code at runtime when it is not present in the config. That allows specifying default system values at compile-time.

@chrisduerr I'm more thinking about the keybindings... I don't see a good way to deal with them without some kind of `include` or conditional `include` like feature. "Inherited" configuration to me is just a system of implicit `include`s.

issue.title: Adding support for an include directive in the config file
issue.body:
For most other applications I have set up my config files such that they are stored on a private git repo, and I can then link to them using the include directives that the config format supports. For example:

- .bashrc: source
- .inputrc: $include
- .ssh/config: Include
- .tmux.conf: source-file

This obviously isn't a high priority requirement (for now I am just using a symlink). As I am interested in rust I also wouldn't mind having a go at implementing this myself, if you were happy to approve the high level idea.
